results.title: The Impossible takes a little longer
results.creator_credit: Anne Henderson, Barbara Janes, Kathleen Shannon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The Impossible Takes a Little Longer documents the work and personal lives of five physically disabled women. It shows how they are coping with the problems they share with all women, the problems they share with other disabled women and those unique to their particular circumstances. The film affirms that disabled women can lead full and productive lives as workers, as mothers and as valued community members. It informs both disabled women and the able-bodied about the possibilities of adaptations in the workplace, the use of technological aids and the need for support systems if disabled women are to have satisfying and productive lives. The Impossible Takes a Little Longer undermines the stereotypes and prejudices that further hinder a large segment of our population.

results.title: The Invention of the adolescent
results.creator_credit: Patricia Watson, Cecily Burwash, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: From the past, when distinctions between childhood and adulthood were not as finely drawn as they are today, this film traces the development of the adolescent and shows some of the real problems of this age. It notes that it was the defense of the young, the protection afforded by reformers and educators, that created the generation gap so evident today in Western society. What adolescents gained and lost from changing attitudes towards them is clearly illustrated in the film. (Awards: New York; La Plata; Tehran)

results.title: The Invasion (1775-1975)
results.creator_credit: Paul Larose and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In 1975, as a Bicentennial special, one thousand American history buffs put on period uniforms and re-enacted the 1775 march of General Benedict Arnold’s troops into Quebec. This short film takes a page of our history which has, perhaps, not yet been completely written. Voice and narration by Griffith Brewer.

results.title: The Insulation story
results.creator_credit: Les Krizsan, Peter Katadotis and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Just as people need layers of clothing to keep warm, so houses need layers of padding to trap warm air and keep it inside as long as possible. The Insulation Story describes how you can get ready for a more comfortable winter with insulation, the not-so-magic formula. The film shows how much of the work can be done by the home-owner at reasonable cost.

results.title: The Insider [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Michael Mann, Eric Roth, Spyglass Entertainment and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: From the opening scene, “The Insider” is a gripping and exhilarating thriller that investigates the corruption of journalist ethics. Russell Crowe gives an effective performance playing against type as Jeffrey Wigand, a paunchy middle-aged business man working for the tobacco industry who decides to blow the whistle on his colleagues’ attempts to hide the health risks associated with smoking. Al Pacino is the television journalist who takes on Jeffrey’s case but who finds that his own media executives refuse to support him. Based on the true story of when a tobacco industry whistleblower approached the US “Sixty Minutes” program, “The Insider” presents a cynical and disturbing case for how the increasing corporatisation of mass media leads to a denigration of the fifth estate’s objectivity and ethics. Michael Mann’s direction in this film is a critical leap for his own artistic career and the purpose and power of his vision is reflected in the high calibre of the support he receives from his cast and crew. The original music score is by Lisa Gerrard and Peter Bourke who are part of the musical group, Dead Can Dance. Cast also includes Christopher Plummer, Gina Gershon, Debi Mazer, Lindsay Crouse, Rip Torn and Philip Baker Hall.

results.title: The Inside story; Tiny Pod and Silverwings
results.brief_description: Two puppet plays which have been designed as a resource for use in drug education programs. Looks at the concept of self, responsibility for self, self confidence and self esteem. By promoting good health and encouraging responsibility for self, it is hoped that young people, if and when faced with the decision to abuse drugs, will have sufficient self confidence and self esteem to make a rational decision. Written and performed by the Skylark Puppet and Mask Theatre.

results.title: The Innocents [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jack Clayton, Achilles Productions, Jack Clayton Productions and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A dark but brilliantly realised adaptation of Henry James’ gothic horror tale ‘Turn of the Screw’. A 19th century British governess (Deborah Kerr) arrives at a bleak mansion to take care of the wealthy household’s two children. Gradually, she begins to believe that there is a malevolent force in the children despite their beatific appearance. While Henry James’ novel leaves little doubt that they have been possessed by the demonic souls of the previous governess and her valet lover, who had died on the estate after an illicit sadomasochistic relationship, the film entertains the possibility that the supernatural events experienced by the governess are merely the product of her vivid imagination. Clayton cleverly uses startling imagery and nerve-bending sound to terrify the audience. Through its use of decor and lighting, and the impressive performances of Kerr and Michael Redgrave as the uncle, the film effectively conveys a claustrophobic sense of repressed hysteria. Cast also includes Megs Jenkins, Pamela Franklin, Martin Stephens and Peter Wyngarde. Also on VHS NTSC [315944].

results.title: The Industrial city
results.creator_credit: Hermann D. Tauchert and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Uses a case study of the industrial city of Detroit in order to present a view of the function of the industrial community in modern American society. Emphasises the fact that the future of a city depends on the education, training and ability of the people. Also discusses the automobile industry where 10,000 cars are produced per day at this time. Touches on the problems of traffic congestion, pollution, poverty and clime.

results.title: The Indian in the cupboard
results.creator_credit: Frank Oz, Frank Marshall, Jane Startz, Kathleen Kennedy, Kennedy/Marshall Company and Scholastic Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Lynne Reid Banks, ‘The Indian in the cupboard’ is a heartwarming adventure about nine year old Omri who magically brings his three-inch toy Indian Little Bear to life. Some of the scenes may not be suitable for very young children however the amazing adventures of these two friends is sure to delight.

results.title: The Immortal battalion = The Way ahead
results.creator_credit: Carol Reed, John Sutro, Norman Walker, G C F and Two Cities Films
results.brief_description: Beginning as a British Army training film called “The New lot”, this film was then expanded into a feature length film written by Eric Ambler and Peter Ustinov, entitled “The Way ahead” for its British audience and re-edited into a slightly shorter film entitled “The Immortal battalion” for an American audience. Its basic concept is as a recruiting and training film for the British Army mixing training and combat footage with filmed sequences. The storyline is about a bunch of raw recruits from a variety of backgrounds who are finally welded into a unified and disciplined regimental unit ready for battle. Stars David Niven, Stanley Holloway, Peter Ustinov, Trevor Howard.
